evidence_span: The oxidation and hydriding kinetics in 400 and 500°C steam have been determined for various grades of Zircaloy.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Over a wide range of corrosion rates, the hydriding kinetics essentially depend on the oxidation rate.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: When the oxidation rate increases, the hydriding rate also rises, but the fraction of the available hydrogen that is absorbed decreases.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Various batches of Zircaloy-4 sheets with standard composition corresponding to ASTM Specification for Zirconium and Zirconium Alloy Strip, Sheet, and Plate (B 551-92), produced either industrially or on a laboratory scale, were selected.
composition_raw: standard composition corresponding to ASTM B 551-92

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Their compositions were tin = 1.4 to 1.5%, iron = 0.20 to 0.21% chromium = 0.10 to 0.11%, and carbon = 0.013 to 0.014%.
composition_raw: tin = 1.4 to 1.5%, iron = 0.20 to 0.21%, chromium = 0.10 to 0.11%, carbon = 0.013 to 0.014%

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: The oxidation kinetics at 400°C are given in Fig. 10. They show that the influence of the Fe/Cr ratio is small over the 2 and 5.8 range, whereas for a ratio of 0.2, an extremely high and virtually linear corrosion rate, is observed.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: for a ratio of 0.2, an extremely high and virtually linear corrosion rate, is observed.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: Table 3 shows that, for the Fe/Cr ratios from 2 to 5.8, for which very similar corrosion kinetics are obtained (Fig. 10), all the relative hydrogen pickup levels are also close to 50%

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: The pickup ratio is extremely small for the grade, with Fe/Cr = 0.2.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: For this alloy, assuming a linear corrosion rate between 0 and 333 days (Fig. 10), together with a linear hydriding rate, the following values are obtained: 1. an oxidation rate of 8.9 mg/dm²/day, and 2. a hydriding rate of 0.2 mg/dm²/day.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: For this alloy, assuming a linear corrosion rate between 0 and 333 days (Fig. 10), together with a linear hydriding rate, the following values are obtained: 1. an oxidation rate of 8.9 mg/dm²/day, and 2. a hydriding rate of 0.2 mg/dm²/day.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: Thus, the value of 19% obtained for the pickup ratio is not the consequence of an intrinsic effect of the Fe/Cr ratio
